messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Naokatsu swordsmith tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Ron, just back from the Sydney Shinsa were we papered a mumei tsuba to Nakatsu or Naooki (he was in charge of Naokatsu s) forge. The guard has been on my
messages.messageBody:
Hi Ron, just back from the Sydney Shinsa were we papered a mumei tsuba
to Nakatsu or Naooki (he was in charge of Naokatsu's) forge. The guard
has been on my mind fore a few days. I used to have a tsuba now with you
by Naooki so I have some stuff kicking about on the group. Let me look
tonight.

Rich

messages.subject: Naokatsu swordsmith tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi All - This is kind of a long-shot unless one of you are interested in shinshin-to smith Jirotaro Naokatsu s work with tsuba. These appear on the market from
messages.messageBody:
Hi All -

This is kind of a long-shot unless one of you are interested in shinshin-to smith Jirotaro Naokatsu's work with tsuba. These appear on the market from time to time, some examples more interesting than others.

Examples of how they are signed seem to range from "Jirotaro Naokatsu" to niji-mei "Naokatsu" to "Fujiwara Naokatsu." Does anyone have any research available if any of these mei-forms indicate the level of his works? Of course what "seems" somewhat logical, his "signed long" tsuba might indicate his better works, but then that's just my personal guess-work.

Ron
STL

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
